name: Kepler-353
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-353 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-353 is a star with 0.39999999999999974 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.5 times its radius. It is located 1268.49 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-353 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-353 b

Kepler-353 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.80 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-353.

The mass of Kepler-353 b is 0.72 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-353 b is 0.89 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-353 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-353 c

Kepler-353 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 8.41 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-353.

The mass of Kepler-353 c is 2.08 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-353 c is 1.38 that of Earth. At 2.08 Earth masses, Kepler-353 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-353, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
